author: @vincenthuaweitien
text: For WSL - Windows users, you need to apply the following command for the crontab command to work.  'service cron status' = to check cron status.  'sudo service cron start' = to run cron service as sudo.  'sudo service cron stop' = to stop cron service as sudo. Optional command.

author: @jakecope8572
text: If anyone wants the template for inside the config. # Example of job definition: # .---------------- minute (0 - 59) # |  .------------- hour (0 - 23) # |  |  .---------- day of month (1 - 31) # |  |  |  .------- month (1 - 12) OR jan,feb,mar,apr ... # |  |  |  |  .---- day of week (0 - 6) (Sunday=0 or 7) OR sun,mon,tue,wed,thu,fri,sat # |  |  |  |  | # *  *  *  *  * user-name  command to be executed

text: If anyone wants to steal Corey's excellent crontab comment, I typed it out:  ``` #  __________ minute (0 - 59) # |  __________ hour (0 - 23) # | |  __________ day of month (1 - 31) # | | |  __________ month (1 - 12) # | | | |  __________ day of week (0 - 6) (Sunday to Sautrday; # | | | | |                                7 is also Sunday on some systems) # | | | | |  # | | | | |  # | | | | |  # * * * * *  command_to_execute ```
